I was just shocked -- shocked! -- to find that Wal-Mart is refusing to carry the video/DVD documentary, Uncovered: The Whole Truth About the Iraq War, because Wal-Mart management considers it "inappropriate".
 
 Here are some other "inappropriate" documentaries you'll never see at Wal-Mart:
 
 The Panama Deception
 
 Hidden Wars of Desert Storm
 
 The Truth and Lies of 9-11
 
 911: The Road to Tyranny
 
 The Money Masters
 
 Manufacturing Consent
 
 Waco: The Rules of Engagement
 
 
 Todd Altman

post_info.post_title: Documentaries Wal-Mart doesn't want you to see

It's their corporate policy to not keep content on their shelves that some people may find offensive.
 
 Just like you won't find many magazines there that you can find in other places...

It's their corporate policy to not keep content on their shelves that some people may find offensive.

 There are countless R-rated movies that plenty of people find "offensive" (e.g., Natural Born Killers, Scarface, Hannibal, etc.), yet Wal-Mart sells them anyway, so that excuse just doesn't wash.
 
 Todd

But those are just movies...

 And these are just documentaries. I've seen far more organized protests against movies over the years than I have against documentaries. In fact, I don't think I've ever seen a documentary evoke the sort of heated reaction that certain movies (e.g., "The Passion of Christ") do . So I say again, the idea that Wal-Mart is acting merely out of a desire to avoid "offending" their customers just doesn't wash.
 
 http://www.walmartwatch.com
 
 Todd Altman

I looked up their policy and what I was talking about was the "Family Values" policy, which doesn't apply to this.
 
 So, now my thought would be that Wal-Mart doesn't want to seem to take a political stance in their stores that could impact customers. You NEVER want to do anything that could alienate your customers, especially in a retail business...
 
 Have they allowed pro-war docmentaries into their stores? Probably not. If they did, then you have a point.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Documentaries Wal-Mart doesn't want you to see
